# Uploading data
Initial cleaned data with baseline covariates + repeated imaging measures. See code to create this can be found at https://github.com/michelle-caunca/HABSRaceEthGenImg.
```{r aim 2 data, include = FALSE}
# Replace with created data
load("./aim2_final_frs.Rdata") # n=3840, v=352
```
## Loading source clinical dataset (baseline)
From HABS-HD data release 6. 
```{r source clinical, include = FALSE}
# loading in source clinical data from baseline
clinical_1 <- read.csv("./clinical hd 1 d6 clean.csv") # n=3838, 1668
view(names(clinical_1))
```
## Creating BP meds variable
The source clinical dataset provides variables that indicate whether a participant is taking meds (taking_medications), and then 25 variables that code free-text medication names. 

At baseline, there are only 252 people who report taking medications per "taking_medications" variable. 

To determine whether folks were taking BP meds, I took the following steps:
1. For each medication_#_name variable, I created a variable bp_med_# that indicated whether there were ANY medications reported that have an indication for chronic HTN. 
- I used UpToDate and my clinical knowledge to screen this.
- I did NOT include HF medications (e.g. Entresto etc), unless they have a specific chronic HTN indication.
- I included most diuretics that could also be used for chronic HTN.
- I did not include anginal medications (e.g. nitrostat). 

I then created a variable that indicated whether a participant had =1 for ANY bp_med_# variable, among those who reported taking medications (taking_medications=1). 

### Selecting medication variables
```{r meds, eval=FALSE, include=FALSE}
# selecting only variables related to taking medciations
takes_meds <- clinical_1 %>%
  select(med_id, 
         taking_medications, 
         (starts_with("medication", ignore.case = TRUE) & ends_with("name", ignore.case = TRUE)),
         (starts_with("medication", ignore.case = TRUE)) & ends_with("frequency", ignore.case = TRUE)) %>% 
  mutate(across(!med_id, as.factor))
# n=3838, v=52
view(names(takes_meds))

# taking a look at the names of meds taken
Hmisc::describe(takes_meds)
summary(takes_meds$medication_1_name)
summary(takes_meds$medication_2_name)
summary(takes_meds$medication_3_name)
summary(takes_meds$medication_4_name)
summary(takes_meds$medication_5_name)
summary(takes_meds$medication_6_name)
summary(takes_meds$medication_25_name)
```

### Creating BP meds variable
```{r BP meds var, eval=FALSE, include=FALSE}
BP_meds2 <- BP_meds %>%
  # count up if ppl reported BP meds across bp_med_#
  mutate(any_BP_meds = rowSums(across(bp_med_1:bp_med_25))) %>%
  mutate(takes_BP_meds = case_when(
    taking_medications == 1 & any_BP_meds > 0 ~ 1,
    taking_medications == 1 & any_BP_meds == 0 ~ 0,
    taking_medications == 0 ~ 0,
    TRUE ~ NA )) %>%
  select(med_id, taking_medications, any_BP_meds, takes_BP_meds)

# checking variables created
summary(as.factor(BP_meds2$any_BP_meds))
summary(as.factor(BP_meds2$takes_BP_meds))
BP_meds2 %>%
  group_by(takes_BP_meds, taking_medications) %>%
  tally() %>%
  spread(takes_BP_meds, n) %>% view()

save(BP_meds2, file = "./analysis data/BP_meds2.Rdata")
```

# Selecting needed variables 
At visit 1: race/ethnicity (exposure), hypertension (mediator), age, gender (confounders not affected by exposure), and years of education and income (confounders affected by exposure). I also added some cardiometabolic and psychosocial variables that predict attrition. 

At visit 2: global amyloid SUVR, med temp tau SUVR, AD-meta ROI cortical thickness, and logWMHV.

From BP_med_2 (derived from source clinical data), we will add newly created takes_BP_meds variable.
```{r want variables, eval=FALSE, include=FALSE}
# load data if needed
load("./aim2_final_frs.Rdata")
load("./analysis data/BP_meds2.Rdata")

# selecting needed variables from our clean aim2 dataset
causmed_1 <- aim2_final_frs %>%
  select(med_id,
         visit_id,
         intdatenew,
         visitcount,
         agenew,
         age_1,
         age_2,
         ethnicity,
         edu,
         gender,
         hasnoinsurance,
         income,
         socsupptot,
         ldl,
         gluc,
         a1c, 
         egfr_nonaa,
         egfr_aa,
         choltot,
         smkever,
         bmi,
         cdx_dep, 
         cdx_htn,
         cdx_cog,
         cdx_dyslipid,
         cdx_cvd,
         cdx_dm,
         sbpavg,
         dbpavg,
         abdaysdiff_1,
         abdaysdiff_2,
         hasabv1,
         hasabv2,
         absuvr_1,
         absuvr_2,
         mriscanner_1,
         mriscanner_2,
         abscanner_1,
         abscanner_2,
         apoe4_positivity,
         apoe4_genotype,
         icv_1,
         taudaysdiff_1,
         taudaysdiff_2,
         taumedtempsuvr_1,
         taumedtempsuvr_2,
         hasmttauv1,
         hasmttauv2,
         tauscanner_1,
         tauscanner_2,
         ctmetaroi_1,
         ctmetaroi_2,
         hasctv1, 
         hasctv2, 
         wmhv_1,
         wmhv_2,
         haswmhv1,
         haswmhv2,
         mridaysdiff_1,
         mridaysdiff_2) # n= 3840, v=60

# clinical
causmed_2 <- clinical_1 %>%
  select(med_id,
         rapa_1_total,
         rapa_2_total,
         gds_total) # n= 3838, v=3

# merging data for analysis
causmed <- causmed_1 %>%
  left_join(causmed_2, join_by(med_id)) %>%
  left_join(BP_meds2, join_by(med_id)) %>%
  mutate(has_htn = case_when(
    (cdx_htn == 1 | takes_BP_meds == 1) ~ 1,
    cdx_htn == 0 ~ 0,
    cdx_htn == 0 & takes_BP_meds == 0 ~ 0,
    TRUE ~ NA)) %>%
  mutate(logwmhv_1 = log(wmhv_1+1)) %>%
  mutate(logwmhv_2 = log(wmhv_2+1)) %>%  
  filter(cdx_cog != 2) # exclude those with dementia at baseline
# n=3592, v=69

# saving dataset
save(causmed, file = "./analysis data/causmed.Rdata")

# cleaning up workspace
rm(causmed, aim2_final_frs, BP_meds, BP_meds2, causmed_1, causmed_2, clinical_1, takes_meds)
```

## Multiple imputation
```{r mice, eval=FALSE, include=FALSE}
# prepping data 
load("./analysis data/causmed.Rdata") #n=3592, v=67
str(causmed)
view(names(causmed))

## identifying categorical variables
catvars <- c("ethnicity", "gender", "hasnoinsurance", 
"smkever", "cdx_dep", "cdx_htn", "cdx_cog", "mriscanner_1", "mriscanner_2",
"cdx_dyslipid", "cdx_cvd", "cdx_dm", "taking_medications", "any_BP_meds", "takes_BP_meds", "has_htn", "apoe4_positivity", "apoe4_genotype", "abscanner_1", "abscanner_2", "tauscanner_1", "tauscanner_2")

## some more data prep
causmed2 <- causmed %>%
  ## re-coding scanner variables to missing if blank 
  mutate(abscanner_1 = ifelse(abscanner_1 == "", NA, abscanner_1)) %>%
  mutate(abscanner_2 = ifelse(abscanner_2 == "", NA, abscanner_2)) %>%
  mutate(mriscanner_1 = ifelse(mriscanner_1 == "", NA, mriscanner_1)) %>%
  mutate(mriscanner_2 = ifelse(mriscanner_2 == "", NA, mriscanner_2)) %>%
  mutate(tauscanner_1 = ifelse(tauscanner_1 == "", NA, tauscanner_1)) %>%
  mutate(tauscanner_2 = ifelse(tauscanner_2 == "", NA, tauscanner_2)) %>% 
  ## converting categorical variable to factor
  mutate(across(all_of(catvars), as.factor)) %>% 
  ## removing some variables that are not needed and might be messing up the imputation due to correlation etc.
  select(!c(agenew, 
            taking_medications,
            any_BP_meds))
summary(causmed2)
view(names(causmed2))

# multiple imputation 
 ## customizing predictor matrix to only include variables that have a min correlation with the outcome 0.4
predictors <- quickpred(causmed2, 
                        mincor = 0.4,
```
